abstract.p: Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton begins broadcasting new 30-second television commercial; ad described; photo (S)

block.p: The Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton began broadcasting this 30-second television commercial this week.
The Senate campaign of Hillary Rodham Clinton began broadcasting this 30-second television commercial this week.
PRODUCER -- Devito/Verdi, with Mandy Grunwald, the Washington media consultant, and Mark Penn, the Washington pollster.

ON THE SCREEN -- The advertisement, Mrs. Clinton's third in this race, shows one image: the first lady speaking. It is the first time she has appeared talking to the camera in one of her ads. The unbroken shot shows Mrs. Clinton in a chair, a blue sweater draped over her neck, as the camera circles her slowly. Soft piano music is heard in the background.

THE SCRIPT -- ''When I started this campaign, I'm not sure I knew quite what to expect, and you probably didn't either. But I've tried to stay focused on our common mission -- making a difference for people. Lifting up our children with better education and health care. Helping our families with tax cuts for college and long-term care. Working to create new jobs. If we reach past our divisions, there's so much we can do working together. I hope you'll give me that chance.''
ACCURACY -- What's to dispute? This is a fairly low-voltage refrain of Mrs. Clinton's stump speech that makes no notable claims of facts or promises.

SCORECARD -- Mrs. Clinton's campaign pushed this onto the air quickly at a time when her aides assumed people would be paying close attention to the race, given Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to step down. The use of the candidate herself is notable, given how unpopular she is among many New Yorkers. The portrayal -- soft camera angles, smiling almost shyly -- seems intended to sand down the harsh edges.
